case_name: Custodian Evacuee Property Punjab v. Jafran Begum

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 772 of 1964 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 772 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 28, 1962 of Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1819 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 28, 1962 of the Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1819 of 1959.

facts.text: House in dispute situated in Malerkotla belonged to Muradbux who died sometime in 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The house in dispute is situate in Malerkotla and belonged to one Muradbux who died Sometime in 1922.

facts.text: In 1947, the house was in possession of Muradbux's son Mohd. Rafiq and widow Jafran Begum.

anchor.surface_text: In 1947, the house was in possession of Muradbuxs son, Mohd. Rafiq and Muradbuxs widow, Jafran Begum.

facts.text: Sometime after partition, Mohd. Rafiq migrated to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime after partition. Mohd. Rafiq migrated to Pakistan. Thereafter numberice was issued under S. 7 of the Act

facts.text: Notice issued under S.7 of the Act to Dildar son of Mohd. Rafiq to show cause why the house be declared evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter numberice was issued under S. 7 of the Act to Dildar son of Mohd. Rafiq to show cause why the house be number declared as evacuee property.

facts.text: No notice issued to respondent Jafran Begum.

anchor.surface_text: No numberice was however issued to respondent Jafran Begum.

facts.text: Dildar appeared before Deputy Custodian and admitted father migrated to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that Dildar appeared before the Deputy Custodian and admitted that his father had migrated to Pakistan.

facts.text: On June 7, 1952, house declared evacuee property. No appeal taken, order final.

anchor.surface_text: So on June 7, 1952, the house was declared to be evacuee property. No appeal was taken against this order which thus became final.

facts.text: On March 2, 1954, respondent filed application before Custodian claiming will by Muradbux in 1918 bequeathing house to her.

anchor.surface_text: However, on March 2 1954, the respondent filed an application before the Custodian claiming that by virtue of a will made in her favour by Muradbux in 1918 he had bequeathed the house to her

facts.text: On July 3, 1954, Custodian held will invalid under Mohammedan law as more than one-third, dismissed application.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore she was the owner of the entire property. On July 3, 1954, the Custodian held that under Mohammedan law a person companyld number will away more than one-third of his property

facts.text: Respondent made representations to Government of PEPSU after dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence the application was dismissed. It seems that thereafter the respondent made some representations to the then Government of PEPSU

facts.text: On September 10, 1956, respondent applied for review of July 3, 1954 order.

anchor.surface_text: but it is number known what happened thereto. On September 10, 1956, the respondent applied for review of the order of the Custodian dated July 3, 1954.

facts.text: Review application dismissed on April 5, 1957 as belated.

anchor.surface_text: That review application was dismissed on April 5, 1957 mainly on the ground that it was belated.

facts.text: Revision to Deputy Custodian General dismissed on September 27, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then went in revision to the Deputy Custodian General but her revision was dismissed on September 27, 1957.

facts.text: On December 3, 1958, Deputy Custodian General suo motu reviewed and held respondent entitled to one-eighth share under Mohammedan law, seven-eighths evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on December 3, 1958, the Deputy Custodian General suo motu reviewed the order of September 27, 1957 holding that the respondent as the widow was entitled to one-eighth share under Mohammedan law.

facts.text: Suit filed by respondent on March 3, 1958 for permanent injunction against Custodian Evacuee Property Punjab and others from evicting her, based on will.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the suit out of which the present appeal has arisen was filed by the respondent on March 3, 1958. She based her case on the will of Muradbux already referred to

facts.text: Trial court dismissed suit on December 31, 1958 holding no civil court jurisdiction due to S.46.

anchor.surface_text: and prayed for a permanent injunction against the Custodian Evacuee Property Punjab and others barring them from evicting her from the house in dispute. The suit was dismissed on December 31, 1958

facts.text: First appeal to Additional District Judge dismissed, holding no jurisdiction relying on Punjab HC decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then went in appeal to the Additional District Judge. The Additional District Judge held relying on certain decisions of the Punjab High Court that civil companyrts had numberjurisdiction

facts.text: Second appeal to Punjab High Court, referred to larger bench, eventually three judges bench held civil courts have jurisdiction on question of title.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then went in second appeal to the High Court. The learned Single Judge who first heard the appeal referred it for decision to a larger Bench.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant obtained special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has companye before us.

facts.text: Muradbux made will in 1918 in favour of Jafran Begum.

anchor.surface_text: claiming that by virtue of a will made in her favour by Muradbux in 1918 he had bequeathed the house to her

facts.text: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, No. 31 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the interpretation of S. 46 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, No. 31 of 1950,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Large scale migration after partition of Punjab in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: As is well known the Act had to be passed in order to deal with the enormous problem which arose on the division of the Punjab and large scale migration

facts.text: Muslims migrated to Pakistan leaving properties in India.

anchor.surface_text: Large numbers of Muslims migrated to that part of the Punjab which is number in Pakistan leaving their properties in that part of the Punjab which is number in India.
A distinction must be made between jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and jurisdiction of civil courts

concepts.interpretation: Jurisdiction under Art. 226 cannot be affected by S.46 of the Act; it is a constitutional power.

issues.text: the only question that arises is the interpretation of S. 46 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, No. 31 of 1950

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the only question that arises is the interpretation of S. 46 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, No. 31 of 1950,  hereinafter referred to as the Act . Brief facts necessary in that connection axe these. The house in dispute is situate in Malerkotla and belonged to one Muradbux who died Sometime in 1922.

issues.text: the question of jurisdiction of civil courts to entertain the suit

anchor.surface_text: The trial court decided the other issues also but we are not concerned with them as in the present appeal only the question of jurisdiction of civil courts to entertain the suit has been raised. The respondent then went in appeal to the Additional District Judge. The Additional District Judge held relying on certain decisions of the Punjab High Court that civil courts had no jurisdiction to entertain a suit of this nature and therefore dismissed the appeal.

issues.text: whether civil courts had jurisdiction in such a case

anchor.surface_text: In consequence a Bench ,of three Judges was constituted to decide whether civil courts had jurisdiction in such a case. The learned Judges were of the view that when a question arose whether any property was or was not ,evacuee property, two matters had to be decided namely- i  whether the particular person had or had not become evacuee and 73 9 whether the property in dispute belonged to him.

issues.text: when a question arose whether any property was or was not evacuee property, two matters had to be decided namely (i) whether the particular person had or had not become evacuee and (ii) whether the property in dispute belonged to him

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges were of the view that when a question arose whether any property was or was not ,evacuee property, two matters had to be decided namely- i  whether the particular person had or had not become evacuee and 73 9 whether the property in dispute belonged to him. On the first question they were of the view that the matter could only be determined by the Custodian and civil courts had nothing to do with it.

issues.text: two questions will arise in every case where the Custodian has to declare whether a property is evacuee property. These two questions are (i) whether a particular person has or has not become an evacuee, and (ii) whether the property in dispute belongs to him

anchor.surface_text: It is clear in view of the definition of evacuee property to which we have already referred, that two questions will arise in every case where the Custodian has to declare whether a property is evacuee property. These two questions are  i  whether a particular person has or has not become an evacuee, and  ii  whether the property in dispute belongs to him. Both these questions have to be decided under s. 7 of the Act by the Custodian.

issues.text: the determination of the Custodian on a question of title if such question arose was not final and the question of title could be reopened in the civil court

anchor.surface_text: They finally decided that the question whether certain person was or was not evacuee was determinable by the Custodian, but the determination of the Custodian on a question of title if such question arose was not final and the question of title could be reopened in the- civil court and was to be finally determined by such court.

issues.text: whether the Custodian under S. 7 acts as a quasi-judicial authority

anchor.surface_text: Clearly the Custodian under S. 7 acts as a quasijudicial authority and so does the authority hearing appeals

issues.text: where the jurisdiction of a tribunal of limited jurisdiction depends upon first finding certain state of facts, it cannot give itself jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: the jurisdiction of a tribunal of limited jurisdiction depends upon first finding certain state of facts, it cannot give itself jurisdiction on a wrong finding of that state of fact. Here under s. 7 the Custodian has to decide whether certain property is or is not evacuee property and his jurisdiction does not depend upon any collateral fact being decided as a condition precedent to his assuming jurisdiction.

issues.text: A distinction must be made between jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and jurisdiction of civil courts

anchor.surface_text: A distinction must be made between jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and jurisdiction of civil courts

arguments.claim: Civil court had no jurisdiction to decide the matter in the face of S. 46 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: and prayed for a permanent injunction against the Custodian Evacuee Property Punjab and others barring them from evicting her from the house in dispute. The suit was dismissed on December 31, 1958

court_response_anchor.surface_text: all have effect numberwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith companytained in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument hav

arguments.court_reasoning: S.46 bars jurisdiction on whether property is evacuee property, including title questions decided under S.7

arguments.claim: Civil courts had no jurisdiction to entertain a suit of this nature relying on Punjab High Court decisions

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then went in appeal to the Additional District Judge. The Additional District Judge held relying on certain decisions of the Punjab High Court that civil courts had no jurisdiction

court_response_anchor.surface_text: all have effect numberwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith companytained in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument hav

arguments.court_reasoning: Consistent with interpretation of S.46 as complete bar

arguments.claim: When question whether property is evacuee property arises, two matters: (i) if person evacuee (Custodian decides), (ii) if property belongs to him (civil court decides if title question)

anchor.surface_text: In consequence a Bench of three Judges was constituted to decide whether civil courts had jurisdiction in such a case. The learned Judges were of the view that when a question arose whether any property was or was not evacuee property, two matters had to be decided namely-

court_response_anchor.surface_text: all have effect numberwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith companytained in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument hav

arguments.court_reasoning: S.7 requires Custodian to decide both questions; no distinction between fact/law or simple/complicated

arguments.claim: The Act provides a complete machinery for adjudication of claims with respect to evacuee property via S.7, appeals S.24, revision S.27

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in Ram Gopal Reddy v. Additional Custodian, the Act thus provides a complete machinery for a person interested in any property to put forward his claims before the authorities competent to deal with the question

arguments.claim: Under S.7, Custodian must decide both (i) whether person is evacuee and (ii) whether property belongs to him

anchor.surface_text: It is clear in view of the definition of evacuee property to which we have already referred, that two questions will arise in every case where the Custodian has to declare whether a property is evacuee property. These two questions are (i) whether a particular person has or has not become an evacuee, and (ii) whether the property in dispute belongs to him.

arguments.claim: S.28 provides finality to orders of Custodian authorities, barring challenge in any court by suit etc.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 which is also important reads thus Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Chapter every order made by the Custodian-General, Custodian, Additional Custodian, Authorised Deputy Custodian, Deputy Custodian or Assistant Custodian shall be final

arguments.claim: S.46 widely worded to bar civil/revenue courts from entertaining question whether property is evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: Section 46 with which we are particularly concerned is in these terms Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act, no civil or revenue court shall have jurisdiction- (a) to entertain or adjudicate upon any question whether any property or any right to or interest in any property is or is not evacuee property

arguments.claim: Custodian under S.7, appellate and revisional authorities act as quasi-judicial authorities

anchor.surface_text: Clearly the Custodian under S. 7 acts as a quasi-judicial authority and so does the authority hearing appeals under s. 24 and the Custodian-General hearing revisions under S. 27.

arguments.claim: No distinction between questions of fact and law or simple vs complicated in Custodian's power under S.7

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we find it possible to make a distinction between questions of fact and questions of law that may arise before the Custodian under s. 7. If he has the power to decide questions of fact... we do not see why he should not have the power of deciding questions of law also.

arguments.claim: Custodian's jurisdiction under S.7 does not depend on collateral fact; distinguishes Mask & Co.

anchor.surface_text: the jurisdiction of a tribunal of limited jurisdiction depends upon first finding certain state of facts, it cannot give itself jurisdiction on a wrong finding of that state of fact. Here under s. 7 the Custodian has to decide whether certain property is or is not evacuee property and his jurisdiction does not depend upon any collateral fact

arguments.claim: S.4 gives overriding effect to the Act over other laws including CPC S.9

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is reinforced by the provision contained in S. 4 of the Act which provides that the Act overrides other laws and would thus override s. 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure on a combined reading of ss. 4, 28 and 46.

arguments.claim: Jurisdiction of High Court under Art.226 unaffected by S.46; distinction from civil courts

anchor.surface_text: A distinction must be made between jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and jurisdiction of civil courts about entertaining civil suits in matters of this kind. Whatever may be the interpretation of s. 46... the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226... cannot be affected thereby.

arguments.claim: By virtue of will made in 1918 by Muradbux, respondent is owner of entire house

anchor.surface_text: However, on March 2 1954, the respondent filed an application before the Custodian claiming that by virtue of a will made in her favour by Muradbux in 1918 he had bequeathed the house to her and therefore she was the owner of the entire property.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: se to her and therefore she was the owner of the entire property. On July 3, 1954, the Custodian held that under Mohammedan law a

arguments.court_reasoning: Will invalid under Mohammedan law as more than one-third

arguments.claim: Under Mohammedan law, will cannot bequeath more than one-third; not proved house was one-third or less

anchor.surface_text: On July 3, 1954, the Custodian held that under Mohammedan law a person could not will away more than one-third of his property and as it had not been proved that the house willed away by Muradbux was one-third of his entire property or less, the will could not be acted upon.

arguments.claim: Respondent as widow entitled to one-eighth share under Mohammedan law; only seven-eighths evacuee property

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on December 3, 1958, the Deputy Custodian General suo motu reviewed the order of September 27, 1957 holding that the respondent as the widow was entitled to one-eighth share under Mohammedan law. He therefore held that only seven-eighths share of the house became evacuee property

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court not concerned with merits, only jurisdiction

arguments.claim: Certain Punjab High Court decisions hold suits barred under S.46

anchor.surface_text: There have been a large number of cases in the Punjab High Court on this question... one holding that suits of this nature were barred while the other view was that where a question of title arose, jurisdiction of civil courts was not barred under S. 46 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: all have effect numberwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith companytained in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument hav

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with view that jurisdiction barred

holdings.text: The jurisdiction of the civil or revenue court is barred under s. 46 and no such court can entertain any suit or adjudicate upon any question whether a particular property or right to or interest therein is or is not evacuee property.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful consideration therefore of the authorities cited before us, we are of opinion that generally speaking the jurisdiction of the civil or revenue court is barred under s. 46 and no such court can entertain any suit or adjudicate upon any question whether a particular property or right to or interest therein is or is not evacuee property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide wording of S.46(a), complete machinery under Act with appeals and revisions, finality under S.28, overrides other laws via S.4.

holdings.text: Two questions arise under S.7: (i) whether person is evacuee, (ii) whether property belongs to him; both to be decided by Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear in view of the definition of evacuee property to which we have already referred, that two questions will arise in every case where the Custodian has to declare whether a property is evacuee property. These two questions are  i  whether a particular person has or has not become an evacuee, and  ii  whether the property in dispute belongs to him. Both these questions have to be decided under s. 7 of the Act by the Custodian.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition of evacuee property requires Custodian to determine both evacuee status and ownership under S.7 inquiry.

holdings.text: Custodian under S.7, appellate authority under S.24, Custodian-General under S.27 act as quasi-judicial authorities.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly the Custodian under S. 7 acts as a quasijudicial authority and so does the authority hearing appeals under s. 24 and the Custodian-General hearing revisions under S. 27.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure of notice, inquiry, order, appeal, revision indicates quasi-judicial nature.

holdings.text: No distinction possible between questions of fact and law, or simple and complicated questions, arising before Custodian under S.7.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we find it possible to make a distinction between questions of fact and questions of law that may arise before the Custodian under s. 7. If he has the power to decide questions of fact... we do not see why he should not have the power of deciding questions of law also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.7 empowers Custodian to decide if property is evacuee property without limitation to fact/simple issues; includes title.

holdings.text: Custodian's jurisdiction under S.7 to decide if property is evacuee property does not depend on any collateral fact.

anchor.surface_text: Here under s. 7 the Custodian has to decide whether certain property is or is not evacuee property and his jurisdiction does not depend upon any collateral fact being decided as a condition precedent to his assuming jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.7 directly empowers decision on evacuee property status; distinguishes collateral fact cases like Mask & Co.

holdings.text: Provisions of the Act including S.4, S.28, S.46 override S.9 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is reinforced by the provision contained in S. 4 of the Act which provides that the Act overrides other laws and would thus override s. 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure on a combined reading of ss. 4, 28 and 46.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.4 gives overriding effect notwithstanding inconsistent laws.

holdings.text: S.28 makes orders of Custodian authorities final and not question-able in any court including by original suit.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 which is also important reads thus Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Chapter every order made by the Custodian- General, Custodian, Additional Custodian, Authorised Deputy Custodian, Deputy Custodian or Assistant Custodian shall be final

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit finality clause bars collateral challenges post exhaustion of remedies.

holdings.text: Distinction between High Court jurisdiction under Art.226 and civil courts jurisdiction; S.46 does not affect Art.226.

anchor.surface_text: A distinction must be made between jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and jurisdiction of civil courts about entertaining civil suits in matters of this kind. Whatever may be the interpretation of s. 46... the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226... cannot be affected thereby.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.226 is constitutional power not limited by statute.

precedents.cited_proposition: cases on jurisdiction of civil courts under S.46 of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act

precedents.citation: Ram Gopal Reddy v. Additional Custodian

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in Ram Gopal Reddy v. Additional Custodian 1 , the Act thus provides a complete machinery for a person interested in any property to put forward his claims before the authorities competent to deal with the question and to go in appeal and

precedents.case_name: Ram Gopal Reddy v Additional Custodian
precedents.cited_proposition: the Act provides a complete machinery for adjudication of all claims with respect to evacuee property

precedents.citation: M. S. Namazi v. Deputy Custodian of E. P.

anchor.surface_text: In M. S. Namazi v. Deputy Custodian of E. P. 1 , the Madras High Court was mainly considering the constitutional validity of the Act. At p. 934, however, Rajmannar C. J. made the following observations There is however one thing about which I am not quite clear.

precedents.case_name: MS Namazi v Deputy Custodian of EP
precedents.cited_proposition: Custodian's order declaring property evacuee is not final on disputed title
precedents.cited_holding: the order of the Custodian or the notification under s. 7 of the Ordinance is not final, in case of disputed title

precedents.citation: Abdul Majid Haji Mohmed v. P. R. Nayak

anchor.surface_text: In Abdul Majid Haji Mohmed v. P. R. Nayak, 1  the main question for consideration was again the constitutional validity of the Act. That was a case which arose on a writ petition.

precedents.case_name: Abdul Majid Haji Mohmed v PR Nayak
precedents.cited_proposition: even if jurisdiction excluded, civil courts can examine non-compliance with Act or lack of judicial procedure

precedents.citation: The Secretary of State v. Mask Co.

anchor.surface_text: Chagla C. J. referred to the decision of the Privy Council in The Secretary of State v. Mask Co. 2  and observed that it was well settled that even if jurisdiction of courts is excluded, civil courts have jurisdiction to examine into cases where the provisions of the Act have not been complied with or the statutory tribunal has not acted in conformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State v Mask Co
precedents.cited_proposition: civil courts retain jurisdiction to check non-compliance with statute or judicial procedure even if jurisdiction excluded

precedents.citation: Firm of Illuri Subbayya Chetty v. State of Andhra Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: However we may add that in Firm of Illuri Subbayya Chetty v. State of Andhra Pradesh 3  this Court observed at p. 763 that the observations in Mask Co.s case 2  were in some respects too widely stated.

precedents.case_name: Firm of Illuri Subbayya Chetty v State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: observations in Mask & Co case were too widely stated

precedents.citation: S. M. Zaki The State of Bihar

anchor.surface_text: The next case to which reference may be made is S. M. Zaki The State of Bihar 4 . There the question was whether the property was evacuee and the court held that the Act had provided adequate remedies and that s. 46 must be construed to mean that the jurisdiction of a civil or revenue court was ousted even if the Custodian had wrongly decided that any property was an evacuee property.

precedents.case_name: SM Zaki v State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: s.46 ousts civil court jurisdiction even if Custodian wrongly decides property is evacuee; no collateral fact issue

precedents.citation: Khalil Ahamad Khan v. Malka Mehar Nigar Begum

anchor.surface_text: The last case to which reference may be made is Khalil Ahamad Khan v. Malka Mehar Nigar Begum 1 . The question there was somewhat different, namely, whether S. 46 bars the jurisdiction of the civil court in a pending matter.

precedents.case_name: Khalil Ahamad Khan v Malka Mehar Nigar Begum
precedents.cited_proposition: s.46 bars civil courts where matter adjudicated under the Act
precedents.cited_holding: in a case where a matter had been adjudicated upon in accordance with the provisions of the Act it might not be possible for courts to interfere

anchor.surface_text: On a careful consideration therefore of the authorities cited before us, we are of opinion that generally speaking the jurisdiction of the civil or revenue court is barred under s. 46 and no such court can entertain any suit or adjudicate upon any question whether a particular property or right to or interest therein is or is not evacuee property.

istent therewith companytained in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument having effect by virtue of any such law. Sections 5 a

anchor.surface_text: It is clear in view of the definition of evacuee property to which we have already referred, that two questions will arise in every case where the Custodian has to declare whether a property is evacuee property. These two questions are  i  whether a particular person has or has not become an evacuee, and  ii  whether the property in dispute belongs to him. Both these questions have to be decided under s. 7 of the Act by the Custodian.
istent therewith companytained in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument having effect by virtue of any such law. Sections 5 a

anchor.surface_text: Clearly the Custodian under S. 7 acts as a quasijudicial authority and so does the authority hearing appeals under s. 24 and the Custodian-General hearing revisions under S. 27.

On a careful companysideration therefore of the authorities cited before us, we are of opinion that generally speaking the jurisdiction of the civil or revenue companyrt is barred under s. 46 and no such companyrt can entertain any suit or adjudicate upon any question whether a particular property or right to or interest in any property is or is

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we find it possible to make a distinction between questions of fact and questions of law that may arise before the Custodian under s. 7. If he has the power to decide questions of fact... we do not see why he should not have the power of deciding questions of law also.

On a careful companysideration therefore of the authorities cited before us, we are of opinion that generally speaking the jurisdiction of the civil or revenue companyrt is barred under s. 46 and no such companyrt can entertain any suit or adjudicate upon any question whether a particular property or right to or interest in any property is or is

anchor.surface_text: Here under s. 7 the Custodian has to decide whether certain property is or is not evacuee property and his jurisdiction does not depend upon any collateral fact being decided as a condition precedent to his assuming jurisdiction.

On a careful companysideration therefore of the authorities cited before us, we are of opinion that generally speaking the jurisdiction of the civil or revenue companyrt is barred under s. 46 and no such companyrt can entertain any suit or adjudicate upon any question whether a particular property or right to or interest in any property is or is

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is reinforced by the provision contained in S. 4 of the Act which provides that the Act overrides other laws and would thus override s. 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure on a combined reading of ss. 4, 28 and 46.

On a careful companysideration therefore of the authorities cited before us, we are of opinion that generally speaking the jurisdiction of the civil or revenue companyrt is barred under s. 46 and no such companyrt can entertain any suit or adjudicate upon any question whether a particular property or right to or interest in any property is or is

anchor.surface_text: A distinction must be made between jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and jurisdiction of civil courts about entertaining civil suits in matters of this kind. Whatever may be the interpretation of s. 46... the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226... cannot be affected thereby.
Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo, C.J. In this app
